skills.name: Recognise visual representations of multiplication times table facts

explanations.A: There are 3 groups of 2 circles, so we have 3 x 2 circles in total.
explanations.B: Not quite - this would mean 3 circles and another 2 circles
explanations.C: The circles are in 3 groups, but we don't have 2 circles in total being shared, we have 2 in each group. Which calculation finds the total of 3 groups of 2?
explanations.D: Not quite - do we have 3 circles, and 3 more circles, and 3 more circles?

explanations.A: Not quite - this would mean 3 circles and another 2 circles
explanations.B: There are 2 groups of 3 circles, so we have 2 x 3 circles in total.
explanations.C: The circles are in 2 groups, but we don't have 3 circles in total being shared, we have 3 in each group. Which calculation finds the total of 2 groups of 3?
explanations.D: Not quite - do we have 2 circles, and 2 more circles?

explanations.A: Careful, I think you mixed up the star and the triangle!
explanations.B: There are 5 groups lined up in the diagram, and each group has 4 squares in it, so we have 5 groups of 4 squares.
explanations.C: 20 is the total number of squares. How many groups are they in? Each circle full of squares is a group...
explanations.D: Not quite - each circle full of squares is a group, so how many groups are there? And how many squares are there in each group?

explanations.A: Careful, I think you mixed up the star and the triangle
explanations.B: 12 is the total number of squares. How many groups are they in? Each circle full of squares is a group...
explanations.C: There are 4 groups lined up in the diagram, and each group has 3 squares in it, so we have 4 groups of 3 squares.
explanations.D: Not quite - each circle full of squares is a group, so how many groups are there? And how many squares are there in each group?

explanations.A: This would mean 3 and 7 put together, but we have 3 whole rows of 7. Which calculation would give us the total number of squares?
explanations.B: We have 3 rows of 7, so 3 x 7 would give the total number of squares in the diagram.
explanations.C: This would mean starting with 3 and taking away 7, but we have 3 whole rows of 7. Which calculation would give us the total number of squares?
explanations.D: This would mean sharing 3 into 7 parts, but we have 3 whole rows of 7. Which calculation would give us the total number of squares?

explanations.A: This would mean 3 and 6 put together, but we have 3 whole rows of 6. Which calculation would give us the total number of squares?
explanations.B: This would mean starting with 3 and taking away 6, but we have 3 whole rows of 6. Which calculation would give us the total number of squares?
explanations.C: We have 3 rows of 6, so 3 x 6 would give the total number of squares in the diagram.
explanations.D: This would mean sharing 3 into 6 parts, but we have 3 whole rows of 6. Which calculation would give us the total number of squares?

explanations.A: We do have 1 group of 8 squares, which is 1 x 8, but are there 0 total squares?
explanations.B: We do have 1 group of 8 squares, which is 1 x 8, but is there only 1 square in total?
explanations.C: We have 1 group of 8 squares, so 1 x 8, and in total there are 8 squares so 1 x 8 = 8.
explanations.D: This would be 1 square and 8 more squares, but we have one group of 8 squares. Which calculation shows 1 group of 8 with the correct total?

explanations.A: We do have 1 group of 10 squares, which is 1 x 10, but are there 0 total squares?
explanations.B: We do have 1 group of 10 squares, which is 1 x 10, but is there only 1 square in total?
explanations.C: This would be 1 square and 10 more squares, but we have one group of 10 squares. Which calculation shows 1 group of 10 with the correct total?
explanations.D: We have 1 group of 10 squares, so 1 x 10, and in total there are 10 squares so 1 x 10 = 10.

explanations.A: This would be 4 and 5 more, but we have 5 jumps of 4 each. Which calculation shows this?
explanations.B: The scale does start at 0 and end at 20, but we aren't multiplying them together... We have 5 jumps of 4 each. Which calculation does this show?
explanations.C: Almost, but this would be 4 jumps of 4 each, and we have 5 jumps of 4 each. Which calculation does this show?
explanations.D: There are 5 jumps of 4 each, so 5 x 4. We can also check that 5 x 4 = 20, as shown on the diagram.

explanations.A: There are 5 jumps of 3 each, so 5 x 3. We can also check that 5 x 3 = 15, as shown on the diagram.
explanations.B: The scale does start at 0 and end at 15, but we aren't multiplying them together... We have 5 jumps of 3 each. Which calculation shows this?
explanations.C: Almost, but this would be 4 jumps of 3 each, and we have 5 jumps of 3 each. Which calculation shows this?
explanations.D: This would be starting with 3 and then adding 5 more, but we have 5 jumps of 3 each. Which calculation shows this?
